docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The Falluja Battle Is Won; Now the Challenge Is Trust As military officials in Falluja prepare to start letting the first residents return, they face a challenge in how to win back the confidence of the people whose city they have just destroyed. American officials say they cannot afford to let this former insurgent bastion become a microcosm of the broader struggle in Iraq -- a rapid military victory followed by a lapse into violence. A1 Prime Minister Ayad Allawi said that he planned to meet with recalcitrant Sunni tribal leaders to persuade them to take part in elections scheduled for Jan. 30. A14 Preparations for U.N. Overhaul The United Nations proposed the most sweeping changes in its history, recommending the overhaul of its top decision-making group, the Security Council, and holding out the possibility that it could grant legitimacy to pre-emptive military strikes. A1 Questions About Annan's Son The chairman of a House subcommittee investigating the United Nations' oil-for-food program in Iraq said in a statement that Secretary General Kofi Annan's son received reimbursements for health insurance coverage from a Swiss inspection company that is being investigated for alleged fraud and abuses in the program. A14 New Vote Offered in Ukraine The man declared the winner of Ukraine's disputed presidential election, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, said he was prepared to accept a new vote and offered not to run again as long as his challenger also stepped aside. Viktor A. Yushchenko, the opposition leader who claims to have won the election, dismissed the proposal. A15 Mending Canadian Fences President Bush traveled to Canada on his first official visit to the country in an effort to try to repair the rift over the war with Iraq. Jean Chrétien, who was prime minister at the time, refused to send troops. A3 Accord Temporary, Iran Says Iran's chief nuclear negotiator said Iran would suspend its uranium enrichment activities while negotiations with Europe for a longer-term accord continued, but would not wholly abandon the program. A3 NATIONAL A18-28 Ridge Announces Plans To Vacate Homeland Post Tom Ridge, who as the first secretary of homeland security led the post-9/11 effort to protect the United States from a terrorist attack at home, said he would leave his job by Feb. 1. A1 Dams in West Will Stay The Bush administration ruled out the possibility of removing federal dams on the Columbia and Snake Rivers to protect 11 endangered species of salmon and steelhead even as a last resort. A1 Board Urges Stay of Execution The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles, in an unusual step, recommended that the execution of a 39-year-old woman be delayed for 120 days so that disputed evidence in the case could be reinvestigated. A18 N.A.A.C.P. Chief to Step Down Kweisi Mfume, the president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said he was stepping down from the helm of the nation's oldest civil rights organization because he wanted a break from the job he has held for nine years. A18 Governor Race Nears End In the still unsettled Washington governor's race, Dino Rossi, the Republican, was declared governor-elect with a lead of just 42 votes, and he used the occasion to increase the pressure on his Democratic opponent to concede. A24 Plans for Stadium Proceed The District of Columbia City Council preliminarily approved to a plan for a new downtown baseball stadium, setting the stage for a final vote that would return major league baseball to the nation's capital. A25 Bush Backs Intelligence Bill President Bush reiterated his support for a sweeping intelligence-overhaul bill and vowed to work with House and Senate leaders to push the bill through Congress. A27 Advocacy Chief Resigns In a surprise shake-up, Cheryl Jacques, president of the nation's largest gay advocacy organization, is resigning immediately, after 11 months on the job, officials said. A21 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Court Panel Demands Billions for City Schools A court-appointed panel has found that an additional $5.6 billion must be spent on New York City's schoolchildren every year to provide the sound, basic education guaranteed in the State Constitution. The finding marks a turning point in a suit that could reshape education financing in the state. A1 Firefighters Killed in Iraq A New York City firefighter serving with the Army National Guard in Iraq was killed when a roadside bomb exploded near his convoy outside Baghdad. On Sunday, a volunteer firefighter from New Jersey was killed while on patrol in Ramadi. B1 New Jersey Turnpike Plans Acting Gov. Richard Codey is expected to announce an estimated $1.3 billion project to expand the New Jersey Turnpike. B1 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-7 Notre Dame Fires Coach The University of Notre Dame dismissed head football coach Tyrone Willingham, opening up what is regarded as the most prestigious job in college sports. D1 Butch Davis resigned as head coach of the Cleveland Browns. D5 ARTS E1-12 Kennedy Auction at Sotheby's Sotheby's is having an auction of some of Caroline Kennedy's possessions. The auction house announced that it would sell some of the contents from the Kennedy house in Hyannis Port, Mass., as well as from family homes in New York, New Jersey and Virginia and on Martha's Vineyard. A1 Dance School to Reopen Dance Theater of Harlem, a financially troubled company, said it would reopen its landmark school on Saturday, thanks to $1.6 million in newly raised donations -- nearly a third of that attributed to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. E1 What is Defeat? After more than $2.5 million in winnings, Ken Jennings -- the ''Jeopardy!'' champion and software engineer from Salt Lake City, finally lost. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Calpers to Fire Its President Sean Harrigan, a prominent figure in the corporate governance movement, said he expected to be ousted as president of the board of California's large public pension fund, in retribution for stands the board had recently taken on topics like executive pay, boardroom cronyism and high health care costs. C1 Pension Fund Sues Merck The pension fund of New York State filed a federal lawsuit against Merck & Company that accused Merck of misleading shareholders about the safety of Vioxx, its now-withdrawn arthritis pain drug. C1 Japan Showing Downturn A string of disappointing economic reports heightened concerns that Japan's recovery from recession may be fading. Industrial output fell 1.6 percent in October from September, while the jobless rate rose and household spending slowed. C1 Business Digest C1 World Business W1 DINING OUT F1-16 EDUCATION B8 OBITUARIES A29 EDITORIAL A30-31 Editorials: Abu Ghraib, Caribbean style; one more round on Iran's nukes; Mr. Ridge's red-alert day. Columns: Nicholas D. Kristof, William Safire. Crossword E4 Public Lives B2 TV Listings E11 Weather D8
